overview: The student proposes an original research topic that contributes to existing bodies of conservation knowledge and is approved by the coordinator. The student then initiates and conducts an involved program of primary research requiring interdisciplinary skills and knowledge. The student conducts the independent research under the guidance of an academic supervisor, and produces a critical research report. The thesis is undertaken across two consecutive semesters and in some cases, access to cultural collections in the field maybe required.
ilo: Demonstrate competence in defining a research question, and in devising and managing an appropriate research path
Use critical reading and analysis skills
Write a report that argues and assesses the research questions and objectives.
generic_skills: Articulation of theoretical and practice-based problems

Prerequisites.content: Students must meet one of the following prerequisite options:
Admission into the 200pt Program course entry point in the MC-CULMC Master of Cultural Materials Conservation
Completion of a minimum of 100 credit points of study
Admission into the 150pt Program course entry point in the MC-CULMC Master of Cultural Materials Conservation
Completion of a minimum of 50 credit points of study
Admission into the 100pt Program course entry point in the MC-CULMC Master of Cultural Materials Conservation

This subject is a capstone in the Master of Cultural Materials Conservation program and is not available to Community Access Program (CAP), Inbound Exchange/Study Abroad or Incoming Cross-institutional students

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.timing: Due at the end of the second semester of enrolment
Due at the end of the second semester of enrolment

date_times.contact_hours: 15 hours: 12 x 1 hour lectures and 3 x 1 hour seminars.
15 hours: 12 x 1 hour lectures and 3 x 1 hour seminars
